summary: This document is a chain of emails from May 2019 among U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff discussing travel approval and reimbursement for a work trip to West Palm Beach, Florida, related to the investigation 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618'. The emails detail travel logistics for prosecutors to interview victims and mention a conflict with a personal trip to San Francisco.

persons.name: Darlene Alleyne
persons.role: Legal Assistant, Public Corruption Unit, U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY)
persons.context: She is the primary correspondent coordinating travel logistics, reimbursement requests, and seeking clarification on procedures for a prosecutor's work trip related to the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Edward Tyrrell
persons.context: He is the approving official for travel requests related to the Epstein investigation, responding to requests from prosecutors and informing staff about reimbursement policies.

persons.name: Alex
persons.role: Assistant U.S. Attorney, Southern District of New York
persons.context: He is a prosecutor actively working on the Epstein investigation, requesting travel approval for victim interviews in Florida and inquiring about reimbursement for a cancelled personal trip.

persons.name: Michele Duncan
persons.context: She is copied on the email chain regarding travel approval and reimbursement for the Epstein investigation, indicating her involvement in the administrative or supervisory process.

persons.name: Wanda Yu
persons.context: She is copied on the email chain regarding travel approval and reimbursement for the Epstein investigation, indicating her involvement in the administrative process.

persons.name: Alison
persons.role: Assistant U.S. Attorney, Southern District of New York
persons.context: She is a prosecutor mentioned as a potential traveler for the Epstein investigation victim interviews in Florida, alongside Alex and Maurene.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.role: Assistant U.S. Attorney, Southern District of New York
persons.context: She is a prosecutor mentioned as a potential traveler for the Epstein investigation victim interviews in Florida, alongside Alex and Alison.

connections.description: Alex requests and receives travel approval from Edward Tyrrell for work on the Epstein investigation.
Darlene Alleyne assists Alex with travel logistics, booking, and reimbursement inquiries for the Epstein investigation trip.
Darlene Alleyne seeks guidance and relays decisions from Edward Tyrrell regarding travel reimbursement policies.
They are both prosecutors working on the Epstein investigation and are scheduled to travel together for victim interviews.
They are both prosecutors working on the Epstein investigation; Maurene is mentioned as a potential travel companion for victim interviews.

events.title: Work Trip to West Palm Beach for Epstein Investigation
events.description: Prosecutors from the SDNY travel to West Palm Beach, Florida, to conduct meetings and interviews with victims as part of the investigation 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618'.

events.title: Cancelled Personal Trip to San Francisco
events.description: Alex cancels a personal trip to San Francisco (for a wedding) due to a scheduling conflict with the work trip to Florida, incurring a $100 cancellation fee.

events.title: Prior Travel Approval for Epstein Investigation
events.description: Alex and Alison receive approval for a prior three-day trip to West Palm Beach, Florida, for meetings and interviews related to the Epstein case.

events.title: Initial Travel Request for Epstein Investigation
events.description: Alex and an unnamed colleague request permission for a two-day trip to West Palm Beach and/or Fort Lauderdale, Florida, for meetings and interviews related to the Epstein case.

locations: New York City, New York (specifically LGA airport)
keyFacts: The emails confirm active investigative work by the SDNY on 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618' in May 2019, involving victim interviews in Florida.
Prosecutors were coordinating tightly scheduled trips, indicating a push to gather evidence and speak with victims.
The government denied reimbursement for a $100 cancellation fee incurred by a prosecutor for a personal trip cancelled due to the Epstein investigation work.
The travel requests mention the need to reserve hotel conference rooms for conducting victim interviews.
The correspondence reveals the internal administrative process (approvals, logistics, reimbursement rules) within the U.S. Attorney's Office for supporting the investigation.
